block.p: A buildup in the atmosphere of two gases that promote global warming has been encouraged by the cultivation of grasslands and the use of nitrogen fertilizer, a new study suggests.
Concentrations of the gases, methane and nitrous oxide, have risen sharply over the last few decades and together account for about 20 percent of total expected global warming, the researchers said.
A buildup in the atmosphere of two gases that promote global warming has been encouraged by the cultivation of grasslands and the use of nitrogen fertilizer, a new study suggests.
Concentrations of the gases, methane and nitrous oxide, have risen sharply over the last few decades and together account for about 20 percent of total expected global warming, the researchers said.
Their study found that cultivation of grasses and use of nitrogen fertilizer make the land absorb less methane and produce more nitrous oxide.
Certain agricultural practices may ease the contribution to the gas buildup, but that is not clear yet, an author of the study, Arvin Mosier, said in a telephone interview.

Mr. Mosier, a research chemist with the United States Agriculture Department's Agricultural Research Service in Fort Collins, Colo., and a colleague, Kevin Bronson, did the work with scientists at Colorado State University in Fort Collins.
The results appear in the current issue of the British journal Nature.

Mr. Mosier said that the study applied to shortgrass prairie, which is found in semiarid regions, and that scientists did not know whether it applied to grasslands in wetter climates across the Great Plains. (AP) SCIENCE WATCH
